author: sky.cactus
content: I find value in review as an editor because it gives a step prior to the end where I can step in and give the EIP a long hard look.  Right now I do this at last call, but that often means the EIP gets its first real substantive feedback after they think they are done.

author: gcolvin
content: <@!301186049323958275>  My take is that an EIP is always under review from the first PR on.  It's not a stage in the process.

author: gcolvin
content: I do think some of this could be resolved with an optional second header where any information about the EIP that is not part of the  editorial process can be maintained.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree, its just that I use that step to *actually* look at it.  ðŸ™‚

author: gcolvin
content: I encourage people to start looking as soon as there is a PR.

author: gcolvin
content: That could take a  load off of the editors

author: sky.cactus
content: As an editor, I look at an EIP when it first is opened as a draft, and then I look at it again when the author tries to change the status (which requires an editor to approve).  I ignore everything between those two steps.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, this means I review once at draft and then once at last call.  I have found that most EIPs entering last call still need a lot of work, so the user *thinks* they are done yet they really aren't that close.  They then do a bunch of revisions, at which point the last call date is incorrect and they have to keep adjusting that up.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would *rather* EIPs enter last call (with a date) once they have had an editor review them fully, in their final form.

author: sky.cactus
content: Review is one way to do this, I'm sure there are other options that would achieve the same goal.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I suppose if Draft => Review doesn't require editor approval then it won't help my process.

author: gcolvin
content: PR->Draft->PR->Draft ... Last Call -> PR -> Draft .> ...  Final Draft

author: gcolvin
content: Easier to think of PRs as edges and Draft, Last Call, and Final as vertices, not sure how notate that.

author: gcolvin
content: Anyway, Editors and others can review work and help the authors get their EIP finalized from before the first PR all the way through.  It's Draft to Last Call and Last Call to Final that require editor approval.

author: gcolvin
content: Most of substantial review happens on the discussions-to thread, with occasional PRs to bring the Draft up to date.  Some authors need more help with PRs, especially if they aren't good at English and/or Git.

author: gcolvin
content: Anyway, As I recall it, part of the intent was - as a practical matter - to minimize the number of places that the Editors needed to exercise their write  permissions on the repository.  And  partly to help avoid political and legal situations like the lost-funds PR that caused Yoichi to  resign.
